elements.title: C++
elements.description: Like it a lot. Large control on ressources, you can't do something wrong without knowing it. Can be hard to compile and debug at times.

elements.title: Java
elements.description: Usefull. Do like the fact that you can have methods and property on enums. A little bit to verbose for me.

elements.title: C#
elements.description: My go to language. Less heavy than Java, but still multiplatform, clear syntax, easy to use, easy to debug, easy to compile, easy to deploy.

elements.title: Python
elements.description: Nice if you want something working fast, easy to use, easy to start, a lot of easily accessible libraries. Do like all the small syntax tricks.

elements.title: TypeScript
elements.description: And Javascript as well. Everything is easy to do, and so is making bad design choices. Promises are a pain.

elements.title: HTML/CSS
elements.description: It does it's job well, even more then you start to compare it to other markup languages (XAML ?).

elements.title: Astro.js
elements.description: Did a lot of that

elements.title: Nuxt
elements.description: Hard to use what you want.

elements.title: Webpack
elements.description: Nice to cleany bundle and nicely separate everything. Should be used on every medium and big project.

elements.title: Vite
elements.description: Simpler and faster than webpack. I really like it.

elements.title: SvelteKit
elements.description: Did a lot of that

elements.title: Vuejs
elements.description: Did a lot of that

elements.title: Angular
elements.description: Did a lot of that

elements.title: React
elements.description: Did a lot of that

elements.title: MySQL
elements.description: Did a lot of that

elements.title: SQL Server
elements.description: Did a lot of that

elements.title: MongoDB
elements.description: Did a lot of that

elements.title: Tensorflow
elements.description: Did a lot of that

elements.title: Keras
elements.description: Did a lot of that

elements.title: Docker
elements.description: Did a lot of that

elements.title: Cordova
elements.description: It's a pain to use, but it's the only way to create a multiplatform (including mobile) app with web technologies.

elements.title: Ionic
elements.description: Corodva without the pain of Cordova. A lot of nice prebuilt components.

elements.title: Kotlin
elements.description: I do like what they did with the language, take some time to accostum to it but I see how it can save a lot of time (even more compared to Java).

elements.title: Flutter
elements.description: Interesting concept, complete API / functionnalites and a lot of plugins. Not realy fan of the fact that it's really easy to mix logic and UI.

elements.title: Maui
elements.description: Way less support than Flutter (Microsoft didn't create any official application with it). A lot of different problems that still need to be isued. In theory it's the future of app development.

elements.title: UWP
elements.description: Did a lot of that

elements.title: WPF
elements.description: Did a lot of that

elements.title: JavaFX
elements.description: If you need to create a multiplatform app without too much work, it's a good choice. Cleary replace Swing for me.

elements.title: SDL2
elements.description: The standard C++ graphic library. Nice to use alongside OpenGL, some discutable design choices then you dive really deep.

elements.title: SFML
elements.description: Way easier to use than SDL2, with the same functionnalities. Great way to start with game development.

elements.title: Tauri
elements.description: Nice alternative to Electron, but still in early development (documentation is lacking and some options are missing).

elements.title: Electron
elements.description: The only mature solution if you a multiplatform desktop app with web technologies. It tend to take a lot of space and ressources.

elements.title: .NET ASP (Framework / Core)
elements.description: Sometime a little bit too magical for me (I like clearly defining the routes, with HTTP verb, route and params). The change from Framework to Core was a pain. Otherwise work really fine.

elements.title: Blazor
elements.description: Nice template system, the syntaxe is pretty natural to use. It became even better with .NET 6.

elements.title: Spring
elements.description: Not really a fan of, some setup like auth is a pain to do (but where is it not).

elements.title: Laravel
elements.description: The right balance between easy to use and powerfull. The documentation is great, base project architecture taught me a lot.

elements.title: Nginx
elements.description: Nice and fast, never encountered a situation where I was limited by it during development.

elements.title: Apache
elements.description: Work as well as nginx but the configuration can be a pain for complexe setups.

elements.title: Express.js
elements.description: Nice framework to create an API on Node.js, have a lot of nice plugins.

elements.title: Fastify.js
elements.description: Greate alternative to Express.js, faster and easy to use.

elements.title: Node.js
elements.description: Large ecosystem with a lot of nice frameworks. Make fullstack development easier.

elements.title: Lumen
elements.description: Realy nice to make API with PHP, not made to host a website.

elements.title: Slim
elements.description: Nice to create small API or website with PHP without the overhead of big frameworks.

elements.title: Swagger
elements.description: Fast to setup and, easy to use. Should be used on every API for documentation.
